Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI investigates several questions regarding moduli spaces by using techniques of algebraic and analytic nature. One main direction of Laza's research program is the construction of geometric compactifications for moduli spaces and the development of tools for studying them. In particular, he is interested in the study of the behavior of the period map at the boundary of the moduli spaces. Another direction is the study of moduli spaces of certain special varieties (K3, Calabi-Yau, and Hyperkahler). In this case, the interplay between geometry, algebra, and arithmetic is the strongest, and consequently one expects a good understanding of the moduli of these varieties. Some of the questions that arise here have direct relevance to string theory.

This is a proposal in algebraic geometry, with connections to the related fields of Complex Geometry and Arithmetic Geometry. Algebraic Geometry is concerned with the study of geometric properties of objects defined by algebraic equations. Within Algebraic Geometry, the PI is interested in the study of moduli spaces, which parameterizes the shapes of objects within a given topological class. This study has connections and applications to several other branches of mathematics and to mathematical physics. The PI is involved in a number of activities that broaden the impact of the proposed research: He is advising graduate and undergraduate students. He is (co)organizing several conferences, as well as a thematic semester on the geometry of Calabi-Yau varieties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research area of the PI is Algebraic Geometry, which is concerned with the study of the geometric objects defined by polynomial equations. Within Algebraic Geometry, the PI is studying moduli spaces. A moduli space is parameterizing in one-to-one manner the geometric objects within a specified class. The moduli spaces are a key tool in mathematics and theoretical physics. In particular, the special case of moduli spaces of Calabi-Yau varieties  plays a central role within String Theory, which gives a general framework for understanding the universe.

This project was concerned with two main directions of study involving moduli spaces. On one hand, the PI has studied the geometry of moduli spaces of special classes of varieties (such that K3 surfaces, or Calabi-Yau threefolds). On the other hand, the PI worked on developing general tools for studying moduli spaces. He has obtained significant results in both directions. More specifically, with K. O'Grady, he has studied the birational geometry of the moduli of K3 surfaces, obtaining a significant enhancement of earlier results of Looijenga, and generalizing the so called Hassett-Keel program to higher dimension. In a different direction (with various collaborators), he has obtained various results relating moduli spaces and period domains - this is well known, and a key tool for abelian varieties and K3 surfaces, but very little was known until this for other more general cases.

The PI has organized a number of scientific events related to the project. In particular, he co-organized a semester-long thematic program on Calabi-Yau varieties at the Fields Institute, and four week-long workshops. Additionally, he co-organized a bi-annual mini-school at Stony Brook, which aims to  introduce the students to algebraic geometry, and speciliazed topics within algebraic geometry.

The PI has mentored and advised several students (both graduate and undergraduate) and postdocs.
